title: 114_hr6510
content: The "Save the Children Act of 2016" is the short title of this legislation. Congress expresses its sense through this act. Congress acknowledges the humanitarian crisis faced by Syrian children due to civil war violence, and the willingness of US citizens and organizations to provide temporary support to these young refugees. Instrumentalities are willing to provide temporary support to young child refugees from Syria during the ongoing humanitarian crisis. The Secretary of State, Attorney General, Secretary of Homeland Security, and Secretary of Health and Human Services should facilitate the temporary relocation and immediate care of up to 25,000 young Syrian minor children refugees who are orphaned or whose proper guardians transfer custody to the United States. The Act aims to bring young Syrian child refugees who are orphaned or whose guardians transfer custody to the United States over three years. Efforts should be made by key officials to reunite or relocate these children back to Syria once the civil war subsides. The Department of Homeland Security and Secretary of Health and Human Services should facilitate family reunification or safe relocation of young Syrian child refugees back to Syria after a substantial reduction in civil war violence and displaced inhabitants. The Save the Children Program is established under Section 3. The Save the Children Program grants visas to young minor children from Syria aged three to ten to enter and stay in the US until there is a significant reduction in civil war violence and displaced inhabitants. After the Department of State designates this time, there is a six-month grace period before the visas expire. The Save the Children Program grants visas to young minor children from Syria aged three to ten to enter and stay in the US until there is a substantial reduction in newly displaced inhabitants. After the Department of State designates this time, there is a six-month grace period before the visas expire, allowing for proper guardianship identification for reunification. Only qualifying children with established guardians present to relinquish custody or orphaned children are eligible for the visa. The Save the Children Program grants visas to young minor children from Syria aged three to ten to enter and stay in the US until there is a substantial reduction in newly displaced inhabitants. The Coordinator of the Program in the United States has supervisory authority for its operations. Only qualifying children with established guardians present to relinquish custody or orphaned children are eligible for the visa. The Coordinator of the Save the Children Program in the United States has supervisory authority over its operations and can appoint additional personnel with approval from the Office of Personnel Management. The Coordinator of the Save the Children Program in the United States can appoint additional personnel with approval from the Office of Personnel Management, including private citizens or federal employees, but cannot set the pay of federal employees. Federal departments or agencies can detail personnel to assist the Coordinator on a reimbursable or nonreimbursable basis. The Coordinator can request personnel from federal departments to assist in carrying out duties under the Act. The Coordinator will utilize resources from the Division of Unaccompanied Children's Services. The Coordinator, under the Act, is responsible for identifying qualifying minor children for the Program and obtaining custody from guardians or establishing orphan status. The Coordinator can request personnel from federal departments and utilize resources from the Division of Unaccompanied Children's Services. The Coordinator is responsible for identifying qualifying minor children for the Program, obtaining custody from guardians, establishing orphan status, and implementing temporary resettlement in the United States. The Coordinator cooperates with relevant authorities and follows applicable laws and international agreements. The Coordinator works with government authorities and NGOs to implement the Program and assist those admitted under it. They consult with key officials on foreign policy and domestic security interests. The Coordinator consults with key officials to ensure the Program's operations align with laws, international agreements, and the goal of family reunification. The Program's operations align with laws, international agreements, and the goal of family reunification, terminating six months after certification by the Secretary of State. The Program in Syria will terminate six months after certification by the Secretary of State of a substantial reduction in civil war violence and newly displaced inhabitants. After a sustained reduction in civil war violence and newly displaced inhabitants in Syria, the Office will work to reunite minor children admitted to the United States with their parents or caretakers, in accordance with international agreements and US laws. The Program in the United States allows minor children to be reunited with their parents or caretakers, following international agreements and US laws. The Program may be suspended or terminated if deemed necessary for foreign policy and domestic security interests. Appropriations are authorized for each fiscal year to support the Program. Appropriations are authorized for each fiscal year to support the Program. Funds can be used from the Migration and Refugee Assistance Act of 1962 for this purpose. The Coordinator must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment detailing the implementation. The Coordinator must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment detailing the implementation of the Program developed under this section. SEC. 4. TEMPORARY NONIMMIGRANT VISA. The Program shall admit up to 5,000 alien minor children aged three to ten in the first year, and 10,000 more in each of the following two years. Preference will be given to children already in custody of the US or its allies outside Syria. This amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to include a Temporary Nonimmigrant Visa. The Immigration Program will admit up to 5,000 alien minor children aged three to ten in the first year, and 10,000 more in each of the following two years, with preference given to children already in custody of the US or its allies outside Syria. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a Temporary Nonimmigrant Visa until the Secretary of State certifies a reduction in civil war violence and displaced Syria inhabitants. The Immigration Program will admit up to 5,000 alien minor children aged three to ten in the first year, and 10,000 more in each of the following two years, with preference given to children already in custody of the US or its allies outside Syria. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a Temporary Nonimmigrant Visa until the Secretary of State certifies a reduction in civil war violence and displaced Syria inhabitants. The Immigration Program will admit alien minor children aged three to ten who are displaced from Syria and approved to reside temporarily in the United States. Alien minor children aged three to ten displaced from Syria can temporarily reside in the United States under the Save the Children Program. They may remain in the US until civil war violence in Syria significantly reduces, as certified by the Secretary of State. Aliens admitted to the United States under the Save the Children Act of 2016 can stay until the Secretary of State certifies a substantial reduction in civil war violence in Syria and newly displaced Syrian inhabitants. A six-month grace period is provided for reunification efforts.
